container-title: Andrews, The Colonial Period of American History

History of German Immigration in the United States (New York, 1908), and G.T.Flom, A History of Norwegian Immigration to the United States...to 1848 (Iowa City, 1909). On the history of the English language in this country, George P.Krapp’s The English Language in America
is still indispensable. H.L.Mencken, The American Language
note: contains much valuable material, although overemphasizing colloquial and vulgar speech. For the supplements and an abridged edition, see above,
and Albert H. Marckwardt, American English (New York, 1958) are readable and informative.
publisher: Thomas Pyles, Words and Ways of American English (New York
title: An excellent one-volume account of the settlement of America is Curtis P.Nettels, The Roots of American Civilization: A History of American Colonial Life
which may be supplemented by the detailed studies of Charles M
The Southern Colonies in the Seventeenth Century, 1607–1698
A careful study of intercommunication between England and colonial America is lan K.Steele, The English Atlantic, 1675–1740: An Exploration of Communication and Community
For the history of the frontier Ray A.Billington’s Western Expansion
is clear and comprehensive. Standard works on the major immigrant groups are Marcus L.Hansen, The Atlantic Migration, 1607–1860
We Who Built America: The Saga of the Immigrant
See also George von Skal

container-title: On the history of language planning and reform in America during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries
note: Emily E.F. Ford, Notes on the Life of Noah Webster (2 vols., New York, 1912
see Dennis E.Baron, Grammar and Good Taste: Reforming the American Language (New Haven, 1982). Excellent introductions to American pronunciation are John S. Kenyon, American Pronunciation
title: The Beginnings of American English
reprints in convenient form some of the earlier discussions of English in America
Mesick’s The English Traveller in America, 1785–1835

gives references to early comments on American speech. A skillful study based on manuscripts of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries is Norman E.Eliason, Tarheel Talk: An Historical Study of the English Language in North Carolina to 1860
There are biographies of Noah Webster by Horace E.Scudder
American Men of Letters Series) and Harry R.Warfel
contains extensive material from Webster’s diaries and correspondence. The fullest account of his work on the dictionary is by Joseph H.Friend, The Development of American Lexicography, 1798–1864
A Linguistic Patriot
The Man Behind the Dictionary
The Spread of German Linguistic Learning in New England during the Lifetime of Noah Webster

note: and Hans Kurath, A Phonology and Prosody The english language in america 385
title: and C.K.Thomas, An Introduction to the Phonetics of American Pronunciation
Studies of the subject based on materials for the Linguistic Atlas are Hans Kurath and
The Pronunciation of English in the Atlantic States

container-title: Atlas of North American English: Phonetics, Phonology and Sound Change
and the same author’s English Pronouncing Dictionary
note: along with John S.Kenyon and Thomas A.Knott, A Pronouncing Dictionary of American English (Springfield, MA, 1949). A.C.Gimson, An Introduction to the Pronunciation of English
title: For other publications associated with the Linguistic Atlas, see the references on pages 376 and 399−400. Recent sociolinguistic dialectology has culminated in a major survey of the changing phonology of American English in William Labov
Comparison with English pronunciation may be made by means of Daniel Jones’s An Outline of English Phonetics

container-title: Surveys of recent and ongoing work in American dialectology are gathered in American Dialect Research
and in Language Variation in North American English: Research and Teaching
title: is useful for recent changes in English pronunciation, and J.Windsor Lewis, A Concise Pronouncing Dictionary of British and American English (London, 1972) conveniently lists the variants side by side. The most up-to-date reference is the Oxford Dictionary of Pronunciation of Current English

container-title: English: Variation and Transition in the American Midwest
title: Representative essays on specific topics are in “Heartland
Focus on the USA

container-title: and Language Variety in the South Revisited
An attempt to present a regional record of the American vocabulary is Harold Wentworth, American Dialect Dictionary
note: which has been superseded by publication of the Dictionary of American Regional English under the editorship of Frederic G.Cassidy.
title: An exhaustive bibliography for the Southern dialect is James B.McMillan and
Annotated Bibliography of Southern American English
Many local word lists will be found in American Speech and the Publications of the American Dialect Society

note: and Brander Matthews, Americanisms and Briticisms (New York, 1892). For an expression of liberal English opinion, see J.Y.T.Greig, Breaking Priscian’s Head (London, 1928).
title: On the subject of Americanisms the principal glossaries and dictionaries have been mentioned on pages 391–93. The American point of view is well represented in T.R. Lounsbury, “The English Language in America

container-title: and Lexicon of Black English (New York, 1977). Edgar W.Schneider’s Morphologische und syntaktische Variablen in amerikanischen Early Black English (Frankfurt a.M., 1981) has been published in an English translation as American Earlier Black English: Morphological and Syntactic Variables
The question of the divergence of the black and white vernaculars is the subject of an issue of American Speech
note: Bibliographies of Black English and related topics in pidgin and creole languages are Ila W.Brasch and Walter M.Brasch, A Comprehensive Bibliography of American Black English (Baton Rouge, 1974) and John E.Reinecke et al., A Bibliography of Pidgin and Creole A history of the english language 386
title: An authoritative and up-to-date account of the most widely studied of all dialects of English is John R.Rickford, African American Vernacular English
John Baugh, Out of the Mouths of Slaves: African American Language and Educational Malpractice
examines the social issues involved. See also the essays in African-American English: Structure, History and Use
Classic essays by William Labov are conveniently collected in Sociolinguistic Patterns (Philadelphia, 1972) and Language in the Inner City: Studies in the Black English Vernacular

R.W.Shuy, W.A.Wolfram, R.W.Fasold, and others have presented the results of their sociolinguistic investigations in volumes of the Urban Language Series, published by the Center for Applied Linguistics. A general survey of sociolinguistics in the United States is Walt Wolfram and R.W.Fasold’s The Study of Social Dialects in American English
Among J.L.Dillard’s sometimes controversial writings, see Black English
A helpful introduction to generative grammar is C.L.Baker’s English Syntax
The historiography of recent linguistics is given a readable treatment by Frederick J.Newmeyer, Linguistic Theory in America
